questions.text: A 19-year-old marine had drowsiness and generalized tiredness, and was brought to the emergency, where after IV administration of saline, he was returned to duty with the diagnosis of dehydration. Upon questioning, he reported unquenchable thirst, and the repeated need to urinate. Although he ate all of his rations as well as whatever he could get from his fellow trainees. On the last day, he complained of vague abdominal pain, which was worse on the morning of admission. He had vomited once. During examination, he was oriented but tachypneic. He appeared pale, dehydrated with dry mucous membranes, and poor skin turgor. His respiratory rate was 36/minute with deep, laborious breathing; his heart rate was 138/minute regular, and his blood pressure was 90/60 Laboratory, on admission, showed glucose of 560 mg/dl, sodium 154, potassium 6. 5, pH 7. 25, bicarbonate 10 mM/liter. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetic ketoacidosis Excessive thirst Polyuria Polyphagia Vomiting Tachypnea Glucose = very high RR = very high = 36/min But still pH = 7. 25 = acidic Therefore we can confirm the diagnosis of Diabetic ketoacidosis due to diabetes mellitus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B : pyelonephritis can be due to elevated glucose in urine, but there is no acidosis or tachypnea in pyelonephritis, so ruled out. Option C: hyperosmolar nonketotic coma, there is no ketosis and no acidosis, therefore can be ruled out. Option D : Melioidosis, by burkholderia pseudomallei, causes abscess in the liver and spleen. Not related here. Can be associated with diabetes, but ruled out in this case.

questions.text: While discussing a case of diabetes mellitus, a resident asked his consultant about diabetes related complications.Which of the following statements is not true regarding diabetes related complications?

options.label: A
options.text: Diabetes related complications can be divided into vascular and non vascular complications

options.label: B
options.text: They are similar for both type 1 and type 2

options.label: C
options.text: Macrovascular complications are diabetes specific, whereas microvascular complications are shared with both general population and diabetes

options.label: D
options.text: Cheiroarthropathy is a nonvascular complication of diabetes

questions.correct_answer: C. Macrovascular complications are diabetes specific, whereas microvascular complications are shared with both general population and diabetes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Macrovascular complications are diabetes specific, whereas microvascular complications are shared with both general population and diabetes Microvascular complications are diabetes specific , whereas Macrovascular complications are shared with both general population and diabetes specific. Microvascular complications are diabetes-specific, whereas macrovascular complications have pathophysiologic features that are both shared with the general population and diabetes-specifi c.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:A,B. Diabetes-related complications can be divided into vascular and nonvascular complications and are similar for type 1 and type 2 DM . The vascular complications of DM are further s ubdivided into microvascular (retinopathy, neuropathy, nephropathy) and macrovascular complications (CHD, peripheral arterial disease [PAD], cerebrovascular disease). Option:D.Nonvascular complications include infections, skin changes, and hearing loss e. g. cheiroarthropathy

questions.text: A clinical case presentation of complications of diabetes mellitus was organized by residents of the medicine department of RNT medical college, rajasthan. The residents elaborated all possible complications , microvascular , macrovascular, non vascular. HOD of the department asked about the possible mechanism by which chronic hyperglycemia can cause all these complications. Which of the following is least likely to be the possible mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperglycemia leads to epigenetic changes that influence gene expression in affected cells

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic hyperglycemia leads to formation of advanced glycosylation end products (eg, pentosidine, glucosepane, and carboxymethyllysine) which bind to specific cell surface receptor

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic hyperglycemia decreases glucose metabolism via the sorbitol pathway related to the enzyme aldose reductase

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic hyperglycemia increases the formation of diacylglycerol, leading to activation of protein kinase c, which alters the transcription of genes

questions.correct_answer: C. Chronic hyperglycemia decreases glucose metabolism via the sorbitol pathway related to the enzyme aldose reductase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic hyperglycemia decreases glucose metabolism via the sorbitol pathway related to the enzyme aldose reductase The correct statement is - Chronic hyperglycemia INCREASES glucose metabolism via the sorbitol pathway related to the enzyme aldose reductase. All other statements are true.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . hyperglycemia leads to epigeneti c changes (Chap. 456) that influence gene expression in affected cells - TRUE Chronic hyperglycemia is the important etiologic factor leading to complications of DM, but the mechanism(s) by which it leads to such diverse cellular and organ dysfunction is unknown. An emerging hypothesis is that hyperglycemia leads to epigenetic changes that influence gene expression in affected cells. Option: B. chronic hyperglycemia leads to formation of advanced glycosylation end products (e. g. , pentosidine, glucosepane, and carboxymethyllysine) which bind to specific cell surface receptors. -TRUE Option: D . Chronic hyperglycemia increases the formation of diacylglycerol, leading to activation of protein kinase C , which alters the transcription of genes - TRUE.

questions.text: A 12 year old male was brought to the casualty with a history of abdominal pain, vomiting since the last few hours. He is found to be dehydrated. The mother says that the child has been losing weight over the last few months. He is also found to have a thyroid swelling. His GRBS is 450 mg/dl and urine ketones are positive. ABG shows metabolic acidosis. He is started on iv fluids and insulin infusion. Given his age and type of presentation, a diagnosis is made. Which is an immunological marker of type I diabetes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti GAD This child has been presented with Diabetic Ketoacidosis which is a common first time presentation of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The associated thyroid swelling probably points to co-existent autoimmune thyroid disease. Individuals with Type 1 DM have the following characteristics- Onset prior to 30 years of age Lean body habitus Requirement of insulin as initial therapy Propensity to develop DKA Increased risk of other autoimmune conditions such as autoimmune thyroid disease, vitiligo, coeliac disease etc Immunologic markers in type 1 DM: Islet cell autoantibodies (ICAs) Glutamic acid decarboxylase, (GAD) Beta cell specific zing transporter (ZnT – 8) Antibody to insulin (IAA) Tyrosine phosphatase (IA-2 & IA- 2B)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Anti endothelial antibody - Antiendothelial cell antibodies (AECAs) are commonly detectable in diseases associated with vascular injury, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), systemic sclerosis, Takayasu arteritis, Wegener granulomatosis, Behçet syndrome, and transplant arteriosclerosis. Option: C . Anti saccharomyces antibody - Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) are immune proteins that are frequently present in people who have inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) .

Extraedge:

Prevention of type 1 DM: In patients with new-onset type 1 diabetes, treatment with anti-CD3 monoclonal antibodies has been tried.

options.label: B

Solution:

Check sensation using 256 Hz tuning fork at the base of the great toe Sensation-vibration sensation [128 Hz tuning fork (NOT 256) at base of great toe]

questions.text: A 45 year old female is newly diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, FBS of 310 and HbA1c 11% is yet to be started on insulin therapy. She is started on a mixed dose of long acting + short acting insulin. Following guidelines are to be followed while mixing short and long acting insulin except?

options.label: A
options.text: Mix the different formulations of insulin in the syringe immediately before injection and inject within half an hour of mixing

options.label: B
options.text: Do not store insulin as a mixture

options.label: C
options.text: Do not mix insulin glargine,detemir or degludec with other insulins

options.label: D
options.text: All the above are true statements

questions.correct_answer: A. Mix the different formulations of insulin in the syringe immediately before injection and inject within half an hour of mixing
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mix the different formulations of insulin in the syringe immediately before injection and inject within half an hour of mixing The alterations in insulin absorption the patient mixes different insulin formulations should NOT prevent mixing insulins The following guidelines MUST be followed while mixing insulins Option:A.Mix the different insulin formulations in the syringe immediately before injection (inject within 2 min after mixing)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:B.Do not store insulin as a mixture Follow the same routine in terms of insulin mixing and administration to standardize the physiologic response to injected insulin Option:C.Do not mix insulin glargine, detemir, or degludec with other insulins

questions.text: The major classes of oral antidiabetic medications include biguanides, sulfonylureas, meglitinide, thiazolidinedione (TZD), dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4) inhibitors, sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT2) inhibitors, and α-glucosidase inhibitors. Which of the following is an antidiabetic drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bromocriptine Recently Bromocriptine has been approved as an antidiabetic drug. It improves glycemic control and glucose tolerance in obese type 2 diabetic patients. Both reductions in fasting and postprandial plasma glucose levels appear to contribute to the improvement in glucose tolerance. The bromocriptine-induced improvement in glycemic control is associated with enhanced maximally stimulated insulin-mediated glucose disposal. However,its role in treatment of type 2 DM is uncertain

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Phenytoin - Phenytoin is used to control certain types of seizures, and to treat and prevent seizures that may begin during or after surgery to the brain or nervous system. Phenytoin is in a class of medications called anticonvulsants. It works by decreasing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Option: C . Ropinirole acts on the nervous system at dopamine receptors (a neurotransmitter or a chemical messenger). It stimulates the dopamine receptors that help restore the balance of natural dopamine in the brain needed to control movements. This medication is available as immediate-release and extended-release tablets.

questions.text: A 48 year old diabetic since 12 years presents with ptosis and ophthalmoplegia suggestive of a 3rd cranial nerve palsy. However direct and indirect pupillary reflexes are normal. Third nerve palsy with normal pupillary reaction is seen in which condition.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetes Cranial Neuropathy = III & VI cranial nerves are commonly involved in diabetes. In DM IIIrd nerve is involved most commonly but pupillary reaction remains normal. In diabetes the central fibers are affected first and not the pupillary fibers. Hence, there is pupillary sparing.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option;A,C. pupillary fibers are peripherally distributed and first affected in case of aneurysm, trauma etc leading to pupillary dilation and loss of pupillary reflex Option:D. Same goes with raised ICP - causes loss of pupillary reflex Option A ,C and D - The 3rd nerve palsy is associated with a loss of pupillary reflex.

questions.text: Scleredema is an uncommon, but likely underrecognized, fibro mucinous connective-tissue disease. It is characterized clinically by woody induration and hardening of the skin that results from excessive mucin deposition between thickened collagen bundles in the skin's dermis. Scleredema is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetes Skin Involvement in DM Pigmented pretibial papules Necrobiosis lipoidica Acanthosis nigricans Granuloma annulare Lipoatrophy and lipohypertrophy Scleredema Dupuytren’s contracture.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A , B, and D are not associated with scleredema.

questions.text: A 50 year old previously healthy male presents with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. There is no history of intake of oral anti diabetic drugs or insulin. The treating physician considers insulinoma as a diagnosis. Gold standard test for diagnosis of insulinoma is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

72 hour fasting glucose test The most reliable test to diagnose insulinoma is a fast up to 72 h with serum glucose, C-peptide, and insulin measurements every 4–8 h. It is thought to be “gold standard” test for insulinoma

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Plasma glucose levels < 3 mmol/l is not gold standard for diagnosing insulinoma. Option: C. Plasma insulin levels > 6µU/ml is not gold standard for diagnosing insulinoma. Option: D. C-peptide levels < 50 mmol/lit is not gold standard for diagnosing insulinoma.
